reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am already a long time player and backer of the Manyland web-based game and was invited to try out the advert-free Steam version.

Since there are no major differences between the two versions bar the absense of adverts and the free boosts, I will give my impressions of the Manyland experience as a whole, based on my two years playing.

Manyland was created as an online sandbox where people could design solid blocks and place them into the world to create buildings and then whole worlds. Time has evolved the game to include many different kinds of blocks, ones which move, or change, ones which interact with Manyland and ones which interact with the wider internet. All these blocks have allowed users to create the most amazing things.

Users have created worlds which are genuinely beautiful, games which are technically complex and adventures that spread for tens of thousands of blocks. The most important thing created however is the community; the Manyland community or Manyzens as they are styled are amazing. They are fiercly protective of their world, nurturing of new players and constantly feed back to the developpers new ideas and features - more often than not these are implimented into the game.

I have never played a game where the developpers were so keen to listen to the userbase, interact with them in game, and learn from them to improve the user experience.

Come and help as we create a whole universe together and build on a comminity of amazing people.
voteText: 43 of 50 people (86%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I got a key for review purposes.  So I played with an open mind, despite the fact that I'm not a huge fan of sandbox games. And guess what? I had fun! So if you like pixel sandbox games, then I highly recommend it.

+ freedom to do what you want
+ very friendly and social community
+ ever changing world
+ encourages creativity
+ ables you to create your own minigames
+ engaged developpers

- many menus
- clueless when you start and helpboard is easily missed by eager beginners (like me)
- some text is hardly visable against light backgrounds
- you need to build a few blocks on a shared area before you can create your own area

I didn't mentioned the price yet, because I'll leave that up to you. It is a bit pricey in my opinion as you could p2f on your browser. So is an ad-free and badge - achievements version worth the price????

more info on my blog: http://www.dragonstrove.net/?p=35

reviewText:
Manyland
Manyland may look a bit simple and even childish at first, but due to it's complexity it ends being a hard game to explain.
Imagine Terraria in a bigger scale, merged with social games like Habbo or Second Life, and a full engine at our disposal to create almost anything. Interested? I was too, and thankfully the game ended up being better than I expected.

You start off in one of the welcome areas, surrounded by random people without any clue of what to do next. But just like the games I mentioned, there are hundreds of rooms for us to choose. In Manyland they are all divided in categories, such as Art, Cinema, Chat, Adventure, Games, Quest, Music, Party, Horror, Casino, and the list goes on and on.

There is unlimited content thanks to the possibility of creating our own items and character models, and then using them to build something entirely new. Maybe a costume party, a giant pool with robots, minigames, a cinema that actually plays videos from YouTube. There is literally no limit but our imagination.
We can attach items to our body, such as weapons, furniture, vehicles or even wings. And we can swap our character model anytime we want, either by creating one by ourselves or using one that has been already created by another player. There are specific rooms for these items, and luckily we can use a stash/inventory on a side of the screen to save everything that we like and then use it in our room.

We can build a house from scratch, using different types of floor pieces, stairs, ladders, walls, blocks, doors, anything that we can imagine. The game benefits from the online community and we can find people 24/7.

Being able of creating pretty much anything we want it's one of the highlights of the game, and it's something that I haven't seen in a long time. It can be quite hard to understand it at first, but there are plenty of tutorials, both outside and inside the game.

Playing Manyland with a group of friends it's a really fun and addictive experience, and if you're looking for a game that let's you build mini games, items and entire rooms from scratch, this is a must buy. The community it's always helping to improve it, and the devs are very active.

You can try the free version of the game here:  Manyland Web[manyland.com]

If you liked this review you can find a lot more in our Curator Group: Original Curators Group

reviewText:
I got the key for review purposes; This has not yet affected my review.
Welcome to Manyland!
What's this? Another shifty Minecraft copy? Heck no, this is the best pixel sandbox you will ever want to play!

First Sight (TL;DR)
As stated upper, it might look like some other Minecraft copy nowadays we lay our eyes upon. Noooot so! This game is literally an universe which you can create whatever you heart wants in!

Gameplay
As soon as you boot the game up, you're greeted with a landscape created by the users, said landscape depending where you spawn. Exploring is the most important thing you must do when you spawn! The large community has created dozens of creations for you to interact with.
The pixels makes it all special!
Not only that the whole universe is at your disposition, but you can also shape it however you want! There is a limit, and that limit is your creativity!
The community makes it all a great experience.
The amount of help you receive is enormous and extremely detailed granted that you need to understand the tools in order to shape your world! Not only the guides you can find, but also the people that are so eager to help you out in any situation.
Exploration!
As I stated upper, exploration is mandatory. The creations you can feast your eyes upon are made pixel by pixel, the game lets you designs your environment with a creator full of colours which you can use to bring your surrounding to life!

Graphics
For me, the avast of pixel goodness in this game has pleased my eyes like never.

OST & SFX
Users create it all by themselves!

Pros 'n' Cons
Pros

+Pixels, lots of pixels!
+The community
+Make your own minigames
+Shape your world without limits

Cons

-Have to navigate through many menus

Should you buy it? If you're a huge fan of pixelated games, if you like a good time with your friends or want to meet new people and create together, this is your cup of tea!

If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group:  Follow Original Curator Group

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've had the privelege to watch Manyland grow and change over the course of almost 2 years now and I have to say it is an enigma and a joy. Everyone's experience with Manyland is guaranteed to be different - it is so open ended that nearly anything is possible.

There really is no aim to the game unless you give it one. Whether you want to create a messy workshop where other players have to match parts to broken robots, a sunny beach full of partying celebrities and seashell diving, lock your friends in a haunted mansion, an art museum, a cottage in the woods, a space walk, a funhouse... the tools are at your disposal, all you need is imagination. If you'd rather just explore other people's work, that's fine too!

This game is best played with friends, as the adult player base is a little shy - we mostly hide. If you're looking to make friends be sure to come out to Manyday on the 19th of every month.

Despite having only 2 devs and no official moderators, the game is surprisingly well self-moderated and you have to go looking to find anything terribly inappropriate.

If you are looking for great places to explore - try manyunity.com, a user-made website (Azuros) cataloguing popular areas.

reviewText:
Combine Roblox, a ton of crappy social browser games, and Terarria, and you get this absolute surprise of a sandbox.

I have received a key from the game developers for reviewing purposes. These normally don't affect my reviews.
Manyland is weird, complicated, but so compelling. The tools provided in this unique sandbox are some of the most powerful and unwieldy things ever in these kind of games. But it also does a poor job at explaining them, and while I think the game is freaking awesome, it does come short in really being accessible.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=622726708

The game is playable for free at manyland.com I have played the web version of the game before but the review will not be judging the differences between the two, despite basically being the same in most cases.
Pros:The social interaction with friends and other players is basic but awesome. Got together with a few forum friends on here and it was fun. And weird.
The tools to create objects are very powerful. There's a lot of objects you can make, and there's a lot of potential to be had. You can make all sorts of games, visual objects, and content for the game.
A large load of community-created content. Most of the items/objects in this game were made by other users, and that's pretty rad!
The community is pretty swell as well. Helpful developers, helpful players, and a world ripe of creativity.
Versus Roblox, it's not a craptastic mess with it's business model. The game is mostly completely free, with some monetary items you can buy (like gifts and a subscription fee). The browser version is totally playable too.
Nitpicks:I wish the Steam version of the game could let you directly use links to send you to a world. Maybe embed it in the Paste?
Adding objects in a area with a background tile is kind of problematic. You have to place the Thing" objects in before placing the background objects. This could be remedied by allowing the player to tweak with multiple layers.
Cons:The game

reviewText:
If you want to try this game out WITHOUT paying a cent for it, just use the web version! The link is manyland.com (I usually play the web version, but if you love this game, feel free to help support it on steam!)

This is simply put; the BEST game I have ever played.

Manyland is an innovative game which allows players to create their own blocks. There are a variety of blocks you can create, and the only limit to what you can make is your imagination!

Here are some examples of types there are:

Body - Bodies can be used to create your skin. With custom animations, I'm able to be anything I want to be. You can make a skin as a baseball player, a girl with a dress, or even a dinosaur!

Dynamics - Dynamics are used to animate blocks frame-by-frame. You can use this to make cool animated objects - and much more! If you took the time, you could create a puppy to follow you around!

Interactings - I use this type the most. With interactings, you can create your own games with special commands! If you want a player to get wood for cutting down a tree, you can do it! If you want to make an XP system to keep track of a player's level, you can do it! Interactings make many things possible.

Solids & Backs - Do you just want to make a simple house, with windows? Just take another player's blocks, or create your own! You can custom-design wood for the walls, and create a log-cabin like style for your house's backgrounds! Add chairs, flowers, and windows to spice up your design.

***
Since all the blocks are drawn pixel-by-pixel, you don't have to worry about pre-sets. Everything in this game is hand drawn!

Phillip is a very active and supportive developer which will frequently update and will help assist with most of your troubles. There are many friendly people in the community, and you can make a ton of friends.

- Savant.
(If you see me on Manyland, stop by and say hi to me! c:)

reviewText:
Manyland - a full sandbox social game
I'd like to say that I started playing this game with none expectations, I had no idea of what I was going to get, only knowing it was a 2d sandbox.

Introduction
At your first sight you see a 2d platform-ish pixelized world where people hang out and share their creations, and that is what this game is about.
The world itself is created by players. Everything you see is customizable:
You may draw clothes, create mounts, guns, build houses, cities and even make your own robot... Using a simple programming language you may create a chat bot, or even an NPC for a mini game your designing. That's right, you may create your own mini game. It sure takes time, but that is entirely possible. And again, everything in the world is user made, the world itself is made of players' buildings.

You may try it for free before purchasing the game, check the end of the review for the link.

Now let's talk about the gameplay
Like I said earlier, your only goal is to create things, if you don't feel like using your creativity, just skip it, you're going to make use of your skills and draw stuff, show other people your creations, meet people, make friends, get mad at some, and repeat...

When I said everything is costumizable I meant it, you draw what you're wearing with no restrictions, there isn't any control system, you may be offensive (and face your consequences later) because what you draw is what you get, it doesn't need to be accepted by the moderation team.

If you've seen some art like blocks, mounts, music, or even robots that other people made and you would like to have it in your place, just drag it to your collection! Nothing will stop you from making the most awesome buildings, even if this means using other people's art!

Controls
Controls are easy to get used to... it may be annoying when you're done chatting, because you need to hold w/a/s/d for a bit if you wish to move, otherwise you'll continue chatting as there is no chat window: when you're typing something, people can see what you're typing before you press send, so you may show them how fast you type :p


Chatting
Again, there are no restrictions, If you're over 13 and mature enough, you may experience several different kinds of converstation. I may say most of the players are those Redditors and 9gag guys, so expect dank memes all the time.

Graphics
They're just ok, let's be honest, it's a 2d game, the art you're seeing is user created, it's not fantastic, but isn't ugly either. Sometimes you'll be amazed, sometimes it's nothing that you've never seen.


Pros+ Great variety of stuff
+ Lots of costumization!
+ Full sandbox experience
+ Ok controls
+ Ok community, depending on the areas you're visiting
+ Cute OST, and background sounds
+ You may do and build anything you want, there are almost no limits
+ Nice art if you're into pixelized games
+ Enjoyable experience, great to kill some time and have a nice conversation with a couple fellas.
+ You may play it for free, thus the multiplayer isn't dead, you'll always find like 1k players online
+ The object type interaction" (a type of object you may create) allows you to make really awesome things

reviewText:
Welcome to Manyland!

I'll try to keep this short and sweet.

Maryland is a cute little browser and Steam app game where you and your friends can meet up, build, roleplay, play games, and whatever else you can possibly imagine!

I have quite a few more hours put into the browser version when a friend told me about Manyland originally. I personally like the ability to log in from your tablet, phone, browser, and have it pop up no issue. What I do wish about Manyland is the ability to log into your Steam account from browser, so I could do the exact same thing, pick it up wherever I may be, without needing to be specifically at my desktop to log in progress and hours for the Steam edition. There's almost no difference, other than the lack of small few second advertisements during loading a zone, and the fact that you're helping out these developers.

One thing I absolutely love is the fact that you can just drop in and without an account, can still interact, play, collect, etc. So I can send a non-Manyland playing friend a link to a world where I've built, and they can see it! That's so awesome. I've yet to interact with anybody apart from my own friends I've sent my world link to, so I can't comment on the community too much. Despite the no dating" signs everywhere

reviewText:
Surprisingly fun social game where you can create, play music (a bit limited), chat and share your creations with others.

Some small cons are:

- Some of the UI design and having to navigate through too many windows every now and then.
- Limitations in creating.
- Getting help for an issue & having to use a message board in another world" for it.

I would recommend it for some casual chatting and creation fun!

8/10"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Finally it has released on steam!

Even though there is not very different from Manyland on your browser, it feels as if it's a bit more stable due to it not relying so much on said browser.

Why should you buy it on steam rather than play for free on browser?
Mainly: to support Manyland, other than that I don't really know.

Nonetheless!
It's an amazing game* for most people, the ones enjoying building, drawing, socializing, programmers etc etc!

*IMO Manyland is more of a hub for creativity than a game, since you can use it like a social network, for drawing and for much much more.

Feel free to speak to me if you see me!

- Thumb

reviewText:
(My playtime is so low because I have played prior to the Steam release, on the web version found here[www.manyland.com])

Manyland is a phenomenal MMO, completely based around user-created, pixel-based 'things' which may include platforms, backgrounds, skins for your player, items and so much more. The amount of designs can be counted in the thousands. With these, you can build your very own world.

The editor for designing items and objects is very easy-to-use and fluid, including features such as RGB and supports hexadecimal color codes for specific tones. Each type of creation has limits to how high and wide you can create it, however. When you've created something or you've found a creation you would like to put down, the simplicity and fluidity of placing these creations are very apparant and there's nothing complex about it.

The community are very polite and I have not come across any sour players yet. Simply sitting in the main hub world can find you meeting new people and having fun with the vast amount of items and bodies already created.

I feel the need to also add that the servers are hosted in the United States (as far as I know), however latency is not really a problem at all.

I recommend Manyland for all of these reasons, as well as the unbelievable possibility for countless future creations and interesting worlds. The only real reason to buy on Steam is to play ad-free, however it also comes with 100 free Boosts (visual and cosmetic effects that don't always last longer than 10-20 seconds). Other than that, going to the website itself and giving the game a try is not too bad of an idea. :)

reviewText:
This game is ADDICTIVE to say the least.

It's a chat.
It's a design your own world 2D reality.
It's a game design kit.
It's all online.

When I tried this game for the first time I was hooked. People were very friendly and always tried to help me out when I was new to the game and lost.

One of the most interesting aspects of this game is that you can try out new game theories and game designs you might have planned, and immediately deploy it for testing as people in the game at any time can visit your game area"
date: this makes it possible to try out new game design ideas LIVE
recommended: how many places can you do that?\n\nYou can even to a certain degree - code your own game elements if you don't find the existing game blocks to your satisfaction
hoursPlayed: there's even some Java script blocks were you can code your own spectacular special effects to add to your game
voteText: with the game engine already provided for you - this is an excellent way to try out your javascript stuff and let other people parttake and appreciate your work instantly.\n\nThere's a solid sense of community in Manyland
helpfulPercent: people often get to know each other very closely - young and old
votesHelpful: but older people tend to stick to older people while the younger generation plays in their own worlds
votesTotal: sometimes when some great graphics artist come along to play in Manyland - everyone
votesFunny: either young or old can appreciate the work and go exploring trough awesome artwork from all over the world.\n\nThere are many community events in Manyland
commentsCount: mostly just created by the community members themselves - this could be weekly or monthly competitions where the prizes are basically just the honor and/or a pixel-pocal ornament with your name on it - maybe you'll get a place in the hall of honors?\n\nEven events similar to the Oscars have been held in Manyland (Called Moscars) where community members who have taken their free time to help newbies and other players
column16: maybe done some outstanding service to the community get voted on by the community itself - everyone is free to parttake
column17: at Manylands events - everyone is invited.\n\nTry it today
column18: but beware - you might never return to the old reality again!"

Do you like pixel art? Are you creative? Do you love to socialise? Whether you do or not, this game is for you, and EVERYONE!

Prepare yourself for unlimited amounts of fun! Prepare for a deathmatch! Prepare for parties! Prepare for...a coffee? In Manyland, ANYTHING is possible!

reviewText:
So first of all, let me just say that Manyland has one of the nicest communities of any game I've ever played.
The amount of support I've recieved from the commuity alone is phenominal... And to hear positive things from people saying my creatons are good is really nice!
The game itself is more of a tool than a game... Think of Little Big Planet, it's similar to that except the world in which you build is forever evolving as people add more to it.
You don't crteate levels as such, it's more like a platform where you create your own worlds and can make them into anything you want!
Would I recommend this game? YES!
It's quirky, fun and you can be whatever and make whatever you want!

reviewText:
Well have been playing games like this for a while. And so far seeing the same issues most open games like this has. The game it self has no way to connect with other players that is easy to find. The board system to leave messages can be confusing and easy to miss if you just jump straight into the game. And there is no out side forums or reporting its all in game. And being that there is rampant abuse with people putting dongs and such up its not a place to be lacking info on reporting.
Not saying its there just its hard to find wich leads into another problem nothing is easy to find info on in game and it has alot of convolted ways of putting out info. Games like trove make you do a tutorial with the basics laid out before you even step into the main game here they throw you into a welcome area with 20 other players and no help. and being theres 8 different welcome areas it is confusing. When using the game thrue steam you miss out on the basic info like how to do auto filling, had to find that in wiki. They got the info laid out if you use the browser version and just multi tab but it needs to be tied into the steam version in some way to. As it stands rite now can't recommend this game to most till they work out a better interface for the basics and clean up some of the welcome areas with the softcore porn put in some of the areas.

Edit: After playing a while still think this game needs more work on it before it was released on steam. It comes with problems like legacy issues were some been playing for years already so main areas are spammed with junk so no place to build. Controls are still confusing and nothing on how to use the item editor got to youtube most info. And developer is gaming steam reviews by giving out keys to people and pushing people to change their negative review.

reviewText: The trailers make this game seem perfect. you get your own little space. build whatever you feel like without worry of it being destroyed, and easy access to your friends. However, it is literally the complete opposite. I sat in that elevator for about 15 minutes waiting to find open space, but every single square inch is taken. The only space available has 100% use by everybody. everyone can break things wherever they feel like it. And if you do manage to find any untouched space, your friends can never find it, since it will be so far from spawn. I give this game a 2/10.
